Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: This Sunday, my younger sister invited me to join her and her friends for brunch and a movie. She rarely asks me to come along, and I know she’s been hoping we could spend more time together, especially since she started college. I want to show her that I care and that I value our relationship, so I promised I’d try to make it. But as I looked at my calendar, I realized the brunch overlaps with the church service I usually attend. My church community expects me to be present, not just for worship but also for the fellowship afterward. I feel a deep sense of belonging there, and I know my absence would be noticed. I want to be a good sister, to build that mutual respect and closeness, but I also feel a responsibility to my faith and my church family. The thought of disappointing either side makes my stomach twist. I sit on my bed, phone in hand, torn between texting my sister back with a yes and setting my alarm for church as usual.
